annotation.text: Segment 1

I was born on 5/17/1914 in Ansonia. My parents from Russia. I moved at age 4
to New Haven. I went to Hillhouse High School in 1932, Yale in 1936 and
learned French, German and Italian. I qualified as a teacher but no job because
of depression. I got into the bike business instead. On 8/8/41, I got married.
Phyllis was born 5/30/43. My friends were not married and were drafted.

I was not drafted probably because I was with the bike business—mechanics
drafted. My wife ran the business when I was in service.
Segment 2

In October of 1943, I was inducted. I went to Fort Devens in MA. I was excited
about adventure but sad to leave daughter. I saw my father cry when I left. I was
sent to Mississippi Camp Shelby and put 65th

Infantry 261st

regimental
headquarters. I has basic training and after a few months, troops needed
overseas. They took all privates and PFCs. I was a PFC and sent to Fort Mead. I
Learned to throw a hand grenade. We sailed to England for 6 days in March
1944. We landed in Liverpool and went to [Market Drayton?] where several
weeks slept in quonset hut. One morning on guard duty an English boy came by
on Rally bike and made appointment to meet but sent to France. Omaha beach
D-Day and 30. Then, I was not assigned to any unit but as a replacement. I
stayed in a pup tent. I was assigned to 80th

infantry division Center Intelligence
Corps (CIC) and went to [Guillarard?] near Nancy. The CIC unit had 25
members in 3 or 4 groups.
Segment 3

In CIC, you never wore your grad, only called agents. There was not much to do
in France. I had to protect security of troops—Nazi collaborators. They had good
informants among Free French. [Tom Edington?] his leader. In [Clemington?]
French arrested. French boys who had been in Wehrmacht.
Shortly after the army crossed the Rhine we got busy. My job to arrest Nazis, in
each town the [Ortsgruppenleiter?] party leader there. I had advance information
of who he was. I learned intelligence fast.
Then other influential National Socialist people. One man we arrested in
[Ortsgruppenleiter?] also owned a restaurant and liquor store. My buddy (buddy
system) liked to drink so we took a few bottles. One was sparkling burgundy.
[John Vance?] (brother of Cyrus Vance) was drinking like a fish and I kept one
bottle to drink at the end of the war.
Segment 4

Incidents:
[Ludwigshafen?] walking down the street. The division took the town that
morning. I saw a Jewish star on sidewalk. I looked up and saw an elderly
woman with tears in her eyes turned out to be a Jew married to a German and
under house arrest. She invited me in. In her bedroom, she opened drawer of
dresser and showed clothes with a star. Then she pulled out a Hebrew prayer
book hidden during the war. She gave me a Mandelbrot.
Segment 5

? What did the word Concentration Camp mean to you?
Nothing, I knew Jews were interned there and not treated well but not idea of

what they were really like.
I found out the telephone still working at [Ludwigshafen?] and the city across the
river. So I went to phone building and told manager to disconnect. He said he
didn't know how. I pulled out my 45 and threatened him and he disconnected. A
member of the AP wrote it up.
We were at the front lines. We were shelled. In France I was in a jeep with
another man and 4 Gis drunk crashed into us. I flew out and hurt my head. I
wanted to die at home. Then I thought I could go to Paris. But I had to continue. I
had torn ligaments. I rested near a stove in a house and dove into a cellar.
Back in Germany, I was going to Weimar (shows pick of Jewish cemetery there).
I didn't know camps were there. I was not involved at camps. I was arresting
Nazis. After war in [Kempten?], Bavaria arresting people. I heard about man
bragging that he was the oldest antisemite in [Kempten?]. I arrested him and
found things he had written bragging about anti-Semitic activities. He was a
tailor. I Heard of Jewish man liberated from camp who was a tailor and got him
the Nazi guy's sewing machine.
Segment 6

Nuremberg (shows picture of destruction and picture of the stadium where
honored German guards and Nazi festivals), we had a list of party functionaries
in each town, wrote XXXX reports and sent them back to 9th corps headquarters,
where interrogated and tried. They usually said they were forced to do things.
Then I was assigned to work with [Robert Madson?] who had a strong
background in history and National Socialism. I worked with him as an interpreter
in France then in Germany but he became fairly fluent in German.
We were going to [Altaussee?] to set up headquarters in Gestapo office.
Segment 7

Heydrich in 1943 (sic- shot May 27,1942, died 4 June) was asasinated and
massacred Jews in Lidice. Ernst Kaltenbrunner took his place. He was the head
of military and foreign intelligence. (Describes him) I knew he had a mistress in
Altaussee, [Gisela von Westpark?]. His wife was informed, helped us, lived
nearby.
After a number of locals discovered him hiding in the mountains with his aide,
[Scheidler?]. His wife was living with von Westpark. They invited us to dinner.
Segment 8

We decided on a plan of action. This was mid-May 1945. The plan was for
[Madson?] to dress as an Austrian hunter and go up with a platoon of 15-20
soldiers. My job was to keep the household of women servants and kids under
house arrest all night. The next morning [Bob?] turned up with 2 civilians and
soldiers. Suddenly Mrs. [Scheidler?] rushed off the porch to her husband and
embraced him.
While [Bob?] was arranging pick-up to corps headquarters, [von Westpark?]
asked to speak to Kaltenbrunner before he left. I sat between them at a table.
They said little. He was tried at Nuremberg. After sentenced to death with Goring

and the others, he had a stroke, but a doctor revived him to hang. We did not
have much conversation with him.
Kaltenbrunner had been put in charge of forming the redoubt area, area for last
stand—to build up. Also I had an idea to contact Dulles and deal to collaborators
with American army and attack Russians. I learned this because [Madson?]
made career of Kaltenbrunner and interviewed people. He visited me and we
talked about the incidents.
Kaltenbrunner did not cheat the gallows.
[Bob?] stayed on until the 1946 trials, heard that when Kaltenbrunner got to the
gallows he said "heil Hitler"
Segment 9

I went back to Ebensee. [Bob?] picked me up in Bavaria on way to [Altaussee?].
I had heard of camp there and went. When we get there, Bob claims we broke
the lock; I only remember going in through open gates. We were not attached to
any unit. The men were 60 lbs, skin and bones. (Shows a picture of a prisoner
taken on May 6, 1945). They were sleeping on shelves. Bugs, thin. I decided to
go to crematorium. First, I saw one room size of filming room piled to ceiling in
naked corpses. Before went through a lager where talking in German and
Yiddish and I couldn't understand why they were there. I asked one man who got
insulted. I knew they were Jews but I thought they must have committed some
crime too.
? How did you know about the crematorium?
I think another GI told me.
At crematorium, I saw signs (shows photo copy) that translate to: “Don't want to
feed worms, so burn don't bury me”. I took the sign. Actually I couldn't reach it. I
told a kapo to get a ladder and take it down.
I went to another town. There were Nazi guys sitting in prison waiting for
Americans to pick them up, Came to get guy. I waited till next morning. He
committed suicide. We returned to [Altaussee?].
Segment 10

talked with other GI's. Most hadn't seen camps right after the liberation like we
had. It changed my outlook. I had little Jewish upbringing. After that, I went back
to my roots. [Madson?] (devout Protestant) felt the same way.
Only 1 day in Ebensee. Other troops coming in. Inmates came up—give us food.
I learned later there was a big counterfeit group there making British money.
German guards had orders to shoot them before they left the camp. They were
going to flood England and lower the value of their currency.
Segment 11

? Did you communicate with your family about what you saw?
Not till I got home. I had to be discreet. I went AWOL in Fontainebleau to visit
Paris before I died.

At [Ebensee?], at first I was shocked. I was in disbelief that this could happen.
Then I was angry. I had no mercy on people we arrested after that and at
antisemitism incidents later. When I came back I decided to become a Jewish
boy again. I didn't know how to start. Then B'nai Brith invited me to a breakfast
and I went.
Segment 12

Then there was an Englishman named [Bailey Stuart?] who broadcast
propaganda for the Germans to England. From 1933-38 he was a spy in
England for the Nazis. [Madson?] arrested him. Then captured in England and
sent to Tower of London because member of the nobility. His family got him out
in 1938. He went to Germany and became a German citizen.
I arrested [Eigruker?]. Her husband was Gauleiter of an Austrian district. I
interviewed her at length. She said proudly that Hitler had been in her house.
She also said her grandmother had once been treated by a Jewish doctor.
A Latvian ambassador came in to be arrested so that the Russians wouldn't get
him. Then told to go home. [Bob?] stayed on. Arrested others later. Some of our
informers had been collaborators, such as [Prinz von Hollenlo?].
[George Haris?] (Ebensee prisoner). On 40th anniversary of Ebensee [Bob?]
was there and saw the ceremony and while there ran into [George Haris?]. They
became friendly after John told him about me. [George?] contacted a Yale
alumni officer with a letter for me. This was 10 years ago and he and I
corresponded. (Tells George's history)
